results.title: Industrial weight lifter
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the correct method of lifting heavy objects. A flexible model simulating the human backbone is used to illustrate how discs are “pinched” when weights are lifted while the backbone is curved. Good posture, positioning, and smooth application of lifting power are shown. Demonstrations point out that using the powerful leg muscles with the back straight and vertical increases lifting power. Extremely heavy items can only be handled with a special lifting device.

results.title: Industrial preparation of acetic acid (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Barrie Whatley, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: Describes the process of making acetic acid, by the oxidation of naphtha with air, in a large industrial chemicals factory. Outlines the various stages in developing the process, including laboratory research and pilot plant development.

results.title: Industrial Mysore. Series 2
results.creator_credit: Jagat Murari, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: A further report on Mysore and its products, including carvings in sandalwood and ivory, inlay work, sugar, paper from bamboo pulp, textiles and soap. Work in the Kojar goldfields is shown in some detail.

results.title: Industrial Mysore. Series 1
results.creator_credit: Jagat Murari, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: Mysore is one of the most highly industrialised states in India. Works include the Mysore Iron and Steel Works; the Krishnasagar Dam, where the river Kaveri has been harnessed; Sivasamundrum and Jog Falls; the state-owned porcelain works and power generating station; the aircraft industry and a factory for manufacturing telephones and electronic equipment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jagat Murari, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India

results.title: An Industrial lake port
results.creator_credit: Victor Vicas and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
The film opens in a lighthouse on the Great Lakes where a sailor from the United States Coast Guard is entertaining a grup of visiting Sea Scouts on a tour of the region. Discusses the various industries that take place on the Great Lakes and how in winter when the lakes freeze over, the crews on the cargo ships must work on ocean-going vessels for part of the year when the lakes are not navigable.

results.title: Industrial journey
results.creator_credit: Fred Clarke and Tasmania. Dept. of Film Production
results.brief_description: Surveys Tasmania’s secondary industries, transportation system, and hydro-electric power scheme. Includes carpet and paper mills, zinc and cement works the Mt Lyle copper mines, an aluminium plant, canned frozen and dried food factories. Shows how the ferry service to the mainland handles goods economically as road transports drive on board with their cargo.

results.title: Industrial Japan
results.brief_description: Japan’s economical growth is approximately 10% per year. Japan’s growth in the second half of the 20th century has been described as a miracle. Poorly endowed with raw materials it depends heavily upon its greatest assset - its people. They have developed industrial skills of the highest level and are applying them to the wide range of modern industry which make up the nation’s economic life.

results.title: Industrial city
results.creator_credit: David Haythornthwaite, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Geography”.
A study of industrial agglomeration as exemplified by the heavy industry of Newcastle, New South Wales. Establishes the essential industrial base of iron and steel production and the network of associated and supplier industries. Shows the interaction between coal, transport, steel and people. Raises environmental issues and poses a question: when will the agglomeration become uneconomic?
